there's only one good thing about overwatch now (doesn't involve the actual game)

As an enthusiastic and devoted fan who eagerly pre-ordered the Deluxe Edition of the original Overwatch, my expectations for its sequel, Overwatch 2, were exceptionally high. However, upon delving into the game, it became evident that Blizzard Entertainment had disappointed its loyal player base.

One of the most disheartening aspects is Blizzard's decision to definitively abandon the promised Player vs. Environment (PVE) downloadable content (DLC). As a fervent supporter, I had been eagerly anticipating new PVE content to further immerse myself in the Overwatch universe. Yet, to my dismay, Blizzard confirmed that there would be no additional PVE content following the initial release. This decision was a significant letdown, as it stripped away one of the main attractions that had been teased during the game's development.

Furthermore, the shift in pricing model from the original Overwatch to Overwatch 2 fell short of expectations. As a fan, I recall Blizzard assuring us that Overwatch 2 would also maintain the free-to-play approach, akin to its predecessor. However, this turned out to be misleading, as subsequent updates and new heroes were gated behind a paywall. This alteration in monetization felt like a betrayal of the initial promise, and many players, myself included, felt deceived.

Moreover, the transition to a paid model for character unlocks and updates also hindered the inclusivity and accessibility of the game. The allure of Overwatch was its balanced and equitable approach, where every player had an equal opportunity to unlock new heroes and enjoy updates without financial constraints. With Overwatch 2's new pricing structure, it became increasingly challenging for certain players to keep up with the content, leading to an uneven playing field.

As a devoted fan, I believe Blizzard's handling of Overwatch 2 could have been more transparent and considerate. The choice to abandon PVE content and shift to a paid model for updates and characters feels like a departure from the fan-centric philosophy that initially endeared us to the Overwatch franchise.

In conclusion, as a rational fan who wholeheartedly invested in the Deluxe Edition of the original Overwatch, I can't help but feel disappointed by the direction taken with Overwatch 2. The abandonment of PVE content and the shift to a monetization model that contradicted initial promises has left me, along with many others, questioning the decisions made by Blizzard Entertainment. I sincerely hope that moving forward, Blizzard can reassess their approach and prioritize the trust and satisfaction of their dedicated player base to ensure the enduring success of Overwatch 2.

Wellï¼ŒOverwatch is goodï¼Œso Iâ€™am giving you a bad review.

What I espy before me is a mockery of the original creation, a jeering caricature of the original Overwatch, which is designed to scorn and ridicule those who frolicked about merrily in the first game. 

I recall playing the initial Overwatch either back in late 2016, or 2017. I would have played it from the moment it was released, albeit I foolishly acquired Battleborn instead, which was a dreadful decision. Alas, it matters nowt, for at a later date I did play Overwatch on the PS4 and enjoyed my time immensely. It was via this game that I learnt the true meaning of toxicity, helping build the man I am today. I was accosted for playing Hanzo and Widowmaker, witnessed women freaking out in the microphone due to being flirted with by adolescents and relished at the prospect of envisioning other children being lambasted for having the audacity to speak and sound as though they was below 14.

Why, I still fondly recall the day when a female asked a Genji player to focus on an adversary on the other team, to which he succinctly replied, â€œNo worries, babeâ€. This innocuous comment then prompted an unnecessary, vitriol fuelled tirade from the woman, who began ranting that â€œThis is what every female has to deal with!â€ I hope that hag has since been drowned in a bucket, but alas I fear she continues to roams free, admonishing any who espouse â€˜sexistâ€™ comments. 

In fact, this game taught me much about the dynamic of gender. I learnt that females act like wild hyenaâ€™s towards each other, when they become a rare commodity, tearing at each others throats, so that they are the sole female, who will then be praised, adulated and fawned over by the other males. It is an ingrained characteristic, for if you are the only female, or male in a group of the opposite sex, then you have free reign and become the thrallmaster of all. You are their last salvation, the assurance that humankind will persist. 

There was still more I learnt as well, for when I passed the mantle and began playing Overwatch on PC, I developed thick skin, as opposed to soft and supple hide. The very first time I was told to kill myself was back in either 2017 or 2018 on the Route 66 map, in Overwatch 1. I recall it distinctly, a gentleman and I were getting along rather amiably, working in unison and endeavouring towards victory. Yet, all went awry in the match and in a moment of rage he kindly suggested that I end my life and then promptly exited the game. As I was queuing up for the next match, I felt a mixture of emotions. I was baffled at the prospect that another human would wish such a fate upon another, solely on account of a virtual games performance. But then I reached the epiphany that this is the law of the world, words and mere quibbles should never be taken in earnest, for conduct is worth more than a thousand words uttered. Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words shall only slight me. And if you feel slighted by naughty, profane words, exhibited by adolescents online, then you are merely a hapless beast, a baby who would never independently survive in the wild. While words can spur the hearts of doughty men, it is actions that will prevail. Heft a pen and I shall wield a sword, let us see whose skull is hewn in twain by the end of dawn! 

Consequently, I encountered that same individual the next game. I confronted him over his negative behaviour, all in voice chat mind you, and inexplicably he refused to respond. It was as though he was ashamed of the words he espoused, yet I would not permit him to elude the hook that easily. I made snide comments, I invoked his ire and when the game was done, he fled back to the hillsides from whence he game, like a bog ridden craven.

After all these memories I have cultivated, playing Overwatch 2 dons the mask of foreigner, as though it is a dim reflection of what I genuinely enjoyed all those years ago. Blizzard has altered and besmirched all, no longer can I play a competitive game with all DPS and miraculously triumph, instead it is regulated by stringent requirements on what class you can play. The majority of the characters appear to be locked, presumably behind a paywall, which is baffling. Thatâ€™s not even mentioning the fact that every game plays identically now, it feels as though the health bar for characters has been substantially increased, causing the swift flow of games to have all but eroded and devolved into a bullet sponge fest, which is wholly tedious and exasperating to participate in.

To be candid, playing Overwatch 2 is as though you are looking at your reflection, albeit inverted. While it certainly appears similar, there are aspects and nuances which feel opaque and slightly off. A pebble has been dropped into the lake and now a ripple has obfuscated and left the original creation murky and elusive. The glory and archaic days of Overwatch have vanished and the time of imperfection and daylight robbery in the form of this game has risen!
